seriesJson.title: New England renaissance
seriesJson.description: A dramatic re-creation of the New England Renaissance produced at Boston University. In this part of the series, the Transcendentalists are viewed from the perspective of 1954, when this program was recorded.

node.title: Transcendentalists and us
node.description: A discussion of transcendental influence on modern thought featuring Dr. Perry Miller of Harvard University.

node.title: Trust thyself
node.description: This program focuses on Ralph Waldo Emerson's early life, educational life, associations with friends, and literary activites.

node.title: To be awake is to be alive!
node.description: This program focuses on Henry David Thoreau. It features select quotations from Walden and his other writing.

node.title: Build, therefore, your own world
node.description: The story of the slavery question; religious and educational conflicts in the 1830s and 1840s.

node.title: Concord revisited
node.description: A documentary tour of Concord, Mass., as it was when the program was recorded in 1954, stressing the famous places known because of the Transcendental activity.

node.title: Little strangeness between us
node.description: This program focuses on the story of Nathaniel Hawthorne. Topics include his friends and his literary contributions;  Elizabeth Peabody's Bookstore;  and minor Transcendentalists.

node.title: Brook Farm revisited
node.description: Brook Farm as it is today. Tour conducted by Reverend Harold Arnold, former pastor of the church where Theodore Parker preached.

node.title: High thoughts-simple living
node.description: The conditions under which the Renaissance took place; background material on the Transcendentalists.

node.title: Be ashamed to die
node.description: The activities of Amos Bronson Alcott and Horace Mann in the education field.  Features re-creation of Alcott's Temple School in Boston based on authentic "conversations."

node.title: Within myself an immense force
node.description: The activities and personality of Margaret Fuller; background information in regard to the Dial and Conversations of the Transcendentalists.

node.title: Like a little heaven
node.description: The story of the Brook Farm experiment in West Roxbury and the Fruitlands experiment in the town of Harvard, Massachusetts.

node.title: Family traditions
node.description: Interviews with direct descendants of Emerson and Amos Bronson Alcott on family memories and traditions.

node.title: Revolt against materialism
node.description: Explanation of Transcendental philosophy and its roots.  Selections from works of Parker, Thoreau and Emerson.
